Throwback Thursday

July 18, 2019

Author: Bianca Yang
Email: ipacifics@gmail.com

I was going through some shelves yesterday, trying to find old things to throw away, when I came across a green notebook from my middle school years. I opened it up, expecting to find some illegible stream of consciousness from my 13-year-old self, but I found my old comics instead. Don’t get too excited, these comics don’t have much artistic or storytelling quality to them, but they reminded me of the cool things I used to do, before I went to college and got serious about making myself job-worthy and surviving under the back-crushing workloads. Today’s post is all about prying open the jar of nostalgia I have within me for the activities that filled my “formative”, pre-college years.

  • Comics
    • This was an activity I continued until I started 9th grade, I think. I can’t remember exactly when I started drawing comics, maybe 5th grade.
    • [So it turns out I wasn’t stupid and documented most of the characters at some point].
    • Kaitlyn Joe commissioned comics from me that I never delivered in Mr Covington’s English class in 7th grade.
  • Orchestra (good old Marina Hall)
    • In 5th grade, the middle school orchestra and band came and gave us a performance. This was intended to enlighten us as to the possible instruments we could play if we joined either group. I decided to join orchestra and play viola, because I preferred classical music and because “everyone else wanted to play violin”.
    • The great thing about that school’s program was that it was basically a massive group instrument class. We were given instruments to use free of charge and were taught, from step zero, how to play. I ended up joining the “honors orchestra” in 7th grade.
    • I switched schools in 8th grade. The orchestra in the new school was more advanced, and I wasn’t very serious about pursuing music on my own, so I gave up the instrument after the 8th grade musical (Guys and Dolls), for which I was a pit member.
  • Tennis
    • I played this sport for many years as a child. I continued this sport the longest, even playing it through my second year of college. At some point, my frustration with not having players at my level to hit with and my frustration with not having time to practice caused me to drop it.
    • The other major sport I played growing up was golf. I never had enough patience to really play golf well. I only liked hitting the ball hard and far, so my putting and short game were always disasters.
    • I dabbled in weightlifting during high school, since that was a more fun PE than a sport or generic PE. I eventually got tired of being a gym rat and decided to focus on bodyweight exercises and mobility.
  • Theater
    • I did Odyssey of the Mind in 9th grade and took theater as an art elective between 10th and 11th grade. I was never good at theatre, but it was, I suppose, an ok enough way to spend my art period time.
  • CTY
    • Good old Center for Talented Youth. I took this program twice, once in some kind of math curriculum and once in some kind of architecture curriculum. Neither program was particularly useful.
  • Sailor Lab (Michael Sailor, nanotech)
    • His was the first lab I ever worked in. I’m grateful that he took me in and exposed me to real life research work, even if I was not the brightest bulb in the bunch…
    • Our group had a lot of fun. We went kayaking at the end of the summer and had a final presentation party at the professor’s house.
  • Lanckriet Group (Gert Lanckriet, music)
    • Second lab I went to. Here, I tried to make some progress on learning computer science. I quickly got stuck. This coincided with when I started to spend time learning about Warren Buffett and investing.
    • I am still grateful to Gert for taking me in and for showing me some of the ropes of what development work looks like.
  • Chen Lab (Clark Chen, oncological neurosurgeon)
    • Third lab I went to. This coincided with my attempt to make it in the field of medicine as a young, scrappy 11th grader.
    • Many thanks to Dr. Chen and Johnny and the rest of his team for teaching me about cancer and what biology research is like.
  • Scripps Young Leaders in Healthcare (Scripps Encinitas)
    • Ah, the days when I thought healthcare was a field I could make some useful contribution towards.
    • Although I never ended up having a strong love for healthcare and all things medicine, this and the summer internship were great programs that exposed me to all kinds of professions within medicine. Many thanks to Dr. Andrew Accardi and the YLHC team for organizing something so amazing for the local youth.
  • Chinese school (SDCA, Chinese Academy, held out of La Jolla Country Day)
    • I went to Chinese school through 7th grade. This was a good source of weekend fun for me. My mom still keeps in touch with many of the other moms who sent their kids to this school or taught at this school. I have not talked to many of my former classmates since I left the school.
